accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to researchers without restrictions.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift from George Conoly Phillips, March 1977

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: George Conoly Phillips was born on December 17, 1931, in Daytona Beach Florida. He married Charlotte Baird Ferebee, and had three children, Elizabeth Meade, James Conoly, and Charlotte Baird. Phillips was an honor graduate of Maury High School of Norfolk in 1949. He later graduated with his Bachelor's degree in Business Administration from the University of Georgia in 1953. At the University of Georgia he was a member of Omicron Delta Kappa, the National Leadership Honor Society, and a Cadet Colonel of the Air Force R.O.T.C. He received his MBA degree from Old Dominion University in 1976. He served two years as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Air Force.

In 1956, Conoly Phillips and his brother, Tench Phillips opened the Phillips Brothers used car dealership. They founded Phillips Brothers Automoville in 1964. The brothers acquired the Rambler franchise in 1960. In 1964, Tench received the Oldsmobile franchise, and Conoly continued with the Lincoln-Mercury franchise. Conoly Phillips was President, and the later chairman, of Conoly Phillips Lincoln-Mercury. He retired from daily management in 1999 when his company merged with Freedom Automotive. He currently remains a partner in Freedom Automotive.

Conoly Phillips' civic activities have been numerous. He was President of the Tidewater Better Business Bureau in 1967 and 1968, President of the United Drug Abuse Commission from 1970-1976, President of the Northside Rotary Club, First Vice-President of the United Way of Virginia, Member of the Central Budget Committee of the United Communities Fund, Former Representative of the City of Norfolk on the Adult Continuing Education Committee, Vice-President of the Sales and Marketing Executives Club of Tidewater, President of the Tidewater Automobile Dealers Association in 1963, Vice-President and legislative chairman of the Virginia Automobile Dealers Association, Member of the Lincoln-Mercury National Dealer Council, Member of the Board of Directors of the Retail Merchants Association of Tidewater Virginia, Chairman of the Finance and Budget Committee for the Assembly on the Dimensions of Hunger-Malnutrition, member of the Junior Board of Directors Central Y.M.C.A. of Norfolk, Chairman for the Brotherhood Dinner sponsored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews, Board member for the Norfolk Symphony Association, Member of the Men's Advisory Board to the Children's Hospital of the King's Daughters, and Member of the Norfolk and Virginia State Chambers of Commerce.

Conoly Phillips has been active in politics since the mid-1970's. He served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Southeastern Tidewater Opportunity Project, was a member of the Community Development Committee of the Virginia Municipal League, and a member of the Community Development Policy Committee of the National League of Cities. He was first elected to the Norfolk City Council in 1976 and served until 1980. He was reelected to the Norfolk City Council in 1986. He continues to serve on the Norfolk City Council as the chairman of the Council's Finance and Infrastructure Committee. He is also chairman of the Ward's Corner Task Force, Hampton Boulevard Task Force, and the Norfolk Highway Commission. Mr. Phillips is a representative for the City of Norfolk on the Southeastern Public Service Authority (SPSA), and on the Empowerment 2010 Board. He has also chaired the Mayor's Task Force on Drugs and the Norfolk Task Force on Juvenile Incarceration and Foster Care, as well as the Youth Forum Task Force. Conoly Phillips ran unsuccessfully for a U.S. Senate Seat in 1978, considering his campaign a "ministry of the Lord in calling Christians to active political participation."

His religious activities have been very important to him, and included membership in the First Presbyterian Church of Norfolk. He was active in his church serving as a Bible teacher and elder. He was President of the Board of Directors of the Union Mission and Hope Haven Children's Homes, co-founder and president of Proclaim Evangelistic Association (a half-way house for drug addicts). He was assistant to the chairman of the Tidewater Virginia Billy Graham Crusade in 1974, and a member and vice-chairman of the Continuing Crusades Committee. Mr. Phillips also supported the Christian Broadcasting Network, and is a personal friend to Pat Robertson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The papers of George Conoly Phillips date from 1942 to 1978. The collection includes correspondence and paperwork related to the auto dealership; political, civic, and religious activities; as well as personal letters. Also included are advertising information, articles, booklets and pamphlets, financial information and legal agreements, audio cassette tapes, and various artifacts. The bulk of this collection relates to the Phillips Brothers Auto Dealership founded by Conoly and his brother Tench.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: The collection is broken down into the following series: I: Auto Dealership; II. Religious Activities; III. Community / Civic Memberships and Activities; IV. Political Activities; V. Personal Information; VI. Audio Cassettes; and VII. Artifacts.

Series I: Auto Dealership. This series is divided into six sub-series related to the Phillips Auto Dealership. Specifically, this series contains information relating to the day to day running of the dealership. Sub-series A: Advertising and Marketing; B: Finances; C: Leases, Contracts, and other Agreements; D: Personnel, Policies, Procedures, and Customer Relations; E: Automotive Associations; and F: Miscellaneous.

Sub-series A: Advertising and Marketing. This sub-series includes information on Phillips "Very Simple Business" campaign and stationary indicating this; letters of correspondence on this campaign from Leon Shaffer Golnick Advertising, Inc.; several folders of television and radio spots, and other marketing plans from the Matthius and Redmond Advertising Agency from May 1972 to August 1974; Market Surveys; newspaper ad clippings; promotional material for various Lincoln-Mercury automobiles; Ford Lincoln-Mercury Advertising Bulletins from October 1972 to May 1974; information on the 1972 Auto Show at the Norfolk Scope; information on advertising via the Scope's Tele-Spot electronic sign; information on advertising in the Yellow Pages, on billboards, and by other advertising venues. Of particular note are the photos and promotional booklets for various Ford Lincoln-Mercury automobiles of the 1960s and early 1970s found throughout this series and the advertising promos for television and radio spots. There is also a promotional pamphlet and 45 LP on the famous commentator Chet Huntley, and how he can help advertise businesses.

Sub-series B: Finances. This sub-series includes monthly and yearly financial statements dating from July 1957 to August 1974; a sample of checkbook stubs; City taxes and licenses from January 1957 to April 1965; Virginia Corporate Tax Returns for 1959 and 1960, State and Federal Tax Returns for 1963 and 1965; Sales Records from June 1962 to December 1963, 1973 Expense Accounts; Automoville Stockholders Initial Meeting, Deeds, and Bank / Loan paperwork; contributions to various non-profit organizations from 1969 to 1972; 1970 travel and miscellaneous expense reports; and 1970 monthly order worksheets.

Sub-series C: Leases/Contracts/Agreements. The first two folders contain Conoly and Tench Phillips initial agreements and paperwork for founding Phillips Brothers. They include personal financial statements, leases, newspaper articles related to the formation of Phillips Brothers Automoville, and articles on the 1964 Norfolk Business Boom which most likely influenced their decision to found the business. The remainder of this sub-series includes leases dated 1956, 1959, and 1963; a Business Certificate dated March 9, 1969; Contracts and agreements from 1957 to 1975 with the Ford Motor Company, Daimler, Dayton Tire & Rubber Company, Multra Music, and Macke Vending Services; History Dealer Agreements from 1957 to 1963; correspondence and memos from the Ford Motor Company and Ford's Lincoln-Mercury Division from 1968 to 1973; Dealer Tag agreements for demo models 1970-1972; various plans and agreements related to the dealership building and building maintenance; agreements for and purchases of office equipment and supplies; the Computerized Automotive Reporting Service (C.A.R.S.) 1970 to 1974; and information on various automatic car washes for auto dealerships.

Sub-series D: Personnel, Policies, Procedures, Customer Relations. This sub-series includes various employee listings; job descriptions, management initiated memos, policies and procedures from September 1969 to December 1973; Personnel policies and procedures related to Life insurance, hiring policies, and a memo regarding the Equal Employment Executive Order 11246; Ford Marketing and Dealership Training; Go, Inc. training, seminars, and products; Employee awards, prizes, and sales incentives; Multiple Personal Inventory employee testing from the Marketing Survey and Research Corporation; Sample employment applications; notes on effective management; Phillips Oldsmobile newsletters from May 1971 to November 1972; Information on labor relations with an emphasis on curtailing labor union activity; and correspondence to and from customers from April 1968 to November 1973.

Sub-series E: Automotive Associations. This sub-series includes information related to the Automotive Trade Association of Virginia - mainly newsletters and correspondence from the period of May 1968 to February 1972, and one letter dated April 14, 1965; National Automobile Dealers Association (NADA) newsletters, correspondence, speeches, pamphlets, and convention programs from January 1969 to December 1971, and a few soft back books published by NADA; and Tidewater Auto Dealers Association correspondence, surveys, bulletins, regulation booklets, and other information. This sub-series also contains Virginia Motor Vehicle Dealer Directories for 1970 and 1971.

Sub-series F: Miscellaneous. This sub-series includes various business correspondence, including newsletters and bulletins dating from 1970 to 1976; the 1970 and 1971 Norfolk Statistical Digest; a 1973 Highway Fact Book; photos; and the Lincoln Mercury Milestone '72 Award. Of particular interest is the correspondence and pamphlets related to electric cars in 1975.

Series II: Religious Activities. This series includes information on contributions and sponsorships of the Christian Broadcasting Network; Correspondence from March 1969 - November 1973 including letters relating to the 1969 Billy Graham Crusade, a few church programs, newsletters, and reports; various letters regarding Conoly Phillips religious views and activities; newsletters, and miscellaneous material related to the Inter-Varsity Christian Fellowship; Perspective newsletters from July 28, 1971 to June 7, 1972; Tidewater Proclaim correspondence, newsletters, and other material, including letters related to youth outreach, drug abuse, and a picture of Billy Graham; Guideposts, including subscription lists, letters related to distributing these to school teachers, and a sample Guidepost Christmas Card; correspondence, reports, articles, and other material related to his church activity in the First Presbyterian Church of Norfolk, including a May 1966 church directory, church agendas, committees, a few church programs, pamphlets, and conference information. There is also a flyer for the Jesus '78 conference featuring Jim Bakker and Andrae Crouch, among others.

Series III: Community and Civic Memberships and Activities. This series contains information on the community and civic activities of Conoly Phillips. It contains information on the United Drug Abuse Council of Norfolk, including meeting agendas and minutes, grant and financial data, budgets for 1973-1974, mailing lists, personnel lists and resumes, by-laws, organization information, programs, reports, sample stationary, and correspondence for 1972 and 1973; a few items related to the Norfolk Symphony subscription campaign and advertising in the Symphony program in 1968; Tidewater Advertising Review Board 1973 organization and procedures, a few letters of correspondence, a 1974 Board Roster, and a January 1974 Selected Consumer Protection Laws booklet; Tidewater Better Business Bureau correspondence from 1969-1973, plans, 1970-72 budgets reports, 1970 and 1972 Roster of Officers and Directors, pamphlets, 1972-73 Annual Report, newspaper article related to 1968 Officer elections, and minutes from 1973 Board of Directors meetings; Norfolk Chamber of Commerce Statement of Receipts and Expenditures July 31, 1969, an article in the March 1970 edition of New Norfolk Magazine, a 1973 bulletin, and 1973 letter; National Chamber of Commerce pamphlets; the Harbor Club membership and receipts for dues from February 1968 to December 1973; Norfolk Kings Daughters Children's Hospital budget reports 1970-1973, 1971 and 1972 Annual Report, objectives, and various correspondence dated from 1968 to 1973; Tidewater Council of Boy Scouts planning and development, committees, Boy Power / Man Power Booklet and folder, facts, 1967 Annual Report, Scout Camp Posters, 1969 Operating Budget; University of Georgia Alumni Chapter 1967 mailing list, and correspondence dated from May and June 1968; Northside Norfolk Rotary Club correspondence from 1969 to 1973, and 1965 mailing list; Mallory Country Club by-laws, budgets, and correspondence from 1964 to 1970; United Communities Fund by-laws, agendas and minutes, 1970- 1973 Annual Reports and Budgets, 1971 and 1973 Board of Directors Listing, and correspondence from 1970-1973. This series also contains various organization resignation letters for Conoly Phillips from 1967-1970.

Series IV: Political Activities. This series is almost exclusively about Conoly Phillips 1978 campaign for U.S. Senate. It contains correspondence on his religious reasons for running and his stands on the issues, letters from other Democratic Candidates, contact lists, notes, press releases and articles, voter pledge forms, campaign flyers, a travel itinerary and an expense report; Conoly Phillips Biographical Information; the Good News letter interview with Conoly Phillips, the 1977 C.S.F.C. Conservative Register, Democratic Convention nomination methods; maps of Virginia; 1978 Democratic Mass Meeting material including pledges of commitment, procedures and rules, objectives, delegates elected, agendas, and returns; 1978 Virginia Democratic Convention notes, Apportionment of Delegates and Alternatives Lists, Delegate Information for Conoly Phillips, County and City Chairman Lists for Congressional Districts; Congressional District Chairmen lists and District Organizational Summaries; and Committee voting forms for the 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 7th, and 8th Districts; Delegate listings for Congressional Districts. This series also contains various political and civic correspondence dated in 1942 and from August 1969 - December 1973 on issues such as the H.R. 13270 Tax Reform bill, the Postal Reform bill, and the Clean Air Act of 1970, as well as various Hampton Roads concerns, copies of 1970 and 1973 Senator and General Assembly lists, and a 1972 Legislative Bulletin.

Series V: Personal Information. This series contains personal correspondence to and from various friends and business contacts for the period of November 1968-November 1973, a Christmas Card list for 1969- 1970; a Warranty Deed and correspondence related to his Walnut Island Property; and various personal notes.

Series VI: Audio Cassettes. This series contains audio cassettes related to Conoly Phillips 1978 Senate campaign, a tape by Pat Robertson on "Exercising Our Dominion", and a "Men's Prayer Breakfast" speech by Conoly Phillips.

Series VII: Artifacts. This series contains several Phillips Brothers automotive emblems, Phillips Brothers' pens, a Conoly Phillips Lincoln-Mercury business card, a Discover Canada Maple Leaf Pin and Card, political buttons to "Re-Elect U.S. Senator Robertson" and "Stovall Clerk of Circuit Court", and buttons to "Support Norfolk Symphony."
